awd_titl_txt: Quantal Heating of 2D Electrons  in Crossed Electric and Quantizing Magnetic Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
**** TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Recent experiments on 2D electrons, placed in quantizing magnetic fields, have identified a new kind of Joule's heating, which occurs exclusively in conducting quantum systems. The effect is absent in classical systems. The quantal heating produces peculiar spectral distribution of electrons, which deviates significantly from the Fermi-Dirac form. Experiments show that even a weak quantal heating induces exceptionally strong violation of Ohm's Law, changing radically the electron transport. Overheated electrons undergo a transition into a state in which voltage does not depend on current (ZDR state), demonstrating simultaneously an apparent metal-insulator (M-I) transition. These intriguing phenomena as well as some fundamental properties of the quantal heating are not understood and contradictive. This project pursues experiments probing the fundamental properties and limits of the quantal heating, ZDR state and the apparent M-I transition in systems with different quantum electron lifetime - the most essential parameter regulating the heating. The experiments will be done on a set of 2D electron systems, formed in high quality GaAs quantum wells with different density of carbon impurities, which control the quantum lifetime. The research will be accomplished by employing the most advanced tools of experimental science: growth of conducting materials of exceptionally high quality, micro and nano-fabrication, low temperature experiments and sophisticated computer simulations. This project will support education and training of a PhD student in advanced areas of quantum physics and materials research.
 
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT**** 
Heating by electric current is a broadly known effect, which has a vast impact on our everyday lives. Besides its positive practical applications, heating often is an undesirable effect in electric circuits. For example, heating causes enormous energy losses in power lines, which translate to significant capital losses for our economy. Despite the general understanding, in some novel conducting materials many features of the electric heating are very surprising. Recent experiments indicate that the electric current may not increase electron temperature in quantum conductors, which are materials with an atomic-like energy spectrum.  In the quantum conductors the current generates exceptionally strong electron overheating in certain parts of the spectrum and induces enormous variation of conducting properties of these materials, which is valuable for applications. This project will pursue experiments to probe fundamental properties of the extraordinary quantal heating, which are poorly understood and contradictive. This will be accomplished by employing the most advanced tools of experimental science: growth of conducting materials of exceptionally high quality, micro and nano-fabrication, low temperature experiments on quantum conductors and comprehensive computer simulations of the heating. This project will support education and training of a PhD student in these advanced technologies.

por.por_cntn:
Joule heating is a remarkable physical effect which transforms electric energy into heat. This phenomenon has very significant impact on our everyday life. Many useful devices such as different electrical heaters and light bulbs are based on Joule heating. Other devices such as microwave ovens use Joule heating. Even cell phones and computers generate Joule heating. In fact all electrical devices around us produce Joule heating.  Thus the fundamental knowledge on how Joule heating works is very important to get better control on its physical properties.

Our project was focused on investigations of the fundamental properties of Joule heating. We tried to understand the microscopic origin of the heating. Namely how does electric energy transfer into heat? It was known for a long time that important particles responsible for Joule heating are electrons.  In our research we have discovered that quantum nature of electrons plays very important role in the transferring electric energy into heat. The quantum nature of electrons leads to formation of energy bands separated by energy intervals forbidden for electrons – called also energy gaps. We have found that during Joule heating these energy gaps prevent energy flows induced by Joule heating and carried by electrons toward higher energies in the energy space. In fact these quantum energy gaps serve as a very effective thermo-insulation for the hot electrons leading to enormous electron overheating inside the distinct quantum energy bands. We have named this effect as quantal heating.

In the conducted research we have studied the most important parameters affecting quantal heating such as shape of energy bands, quantum electron lifetime, time of energy relaxation of electron. We have found that a modification of the energy bands changes significantly the strength of quantal heating. It opens exciting possibilities for significant improvement of quantal heating via the engineering of novel quantum conducting structures and nanomaterials.

The quantum electron lifetime is another important parameter affecting quantal heating. We note that quantal heating is a quantum phenomenon, which is absent in systems with a classical energy spectrum.  The longer quantum lifetime makes the electron behavior to be more quantum mechanical and, thus, enhances quantal heating. In conducting electron systems accurate measurements of the quantum electron lifetime at different temperatures presents a challenge. In this project we have developed new effective method to access the electron lifetime in a broad range of temperatures. We have measured the quantum lifetime of two dimensional electrons and have found that at high temperatures the lifetime of an electron is determined mostly by a scattering with other electrons.

The scattering with other electrons leads to another important physical property – the electron energy relaxation, which should limit quantal heating. The electron-electron scattering mixes energies of electrons from different energy bands leading to a relaxation of the electron distribution toward thermal equilibrium. This relaxation reduces the effect of quantal heating on the electron transport. In this project we have developed a direct method to measure the energy relaxation. We have found that the relaxation of quantal heating is indeed accomplished via electron-electron scattering at high temperatures. These experiments provide the direct quantitative measure of the fundamental cause limiting quantal heating.

Our study has established that quantal heating is the dominant mechanism leading to outstanding conducting properties of highly mobile electrons, driving them into exotic states in which voltage (current) does not depend on current (voltage). The conducting properties of materials are of paramount importance for many valuable applications and existing devices. Our investigations indicate that these remarkable properties can be modified on demand via appropriate engineering of quantum properties of  materials. It opens new unexplored area for the future engineering development and applications of quantal  heating.
